lexUnit.name: contempt.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the feeling that a person or a thing is worthless or beneath consideration

sentence.text: In that syllable was such contempt that it frightened her .
It was said in a tone of such contempt that Kate felt something inside her break .
Mary Warnock provides a scathing analysis of the government 's attitude to higher education when she writes of the contempt that the government has for universities and their staff :
There was a trace of rebellious contempt at the threat of authority .

There was an icy contempt in her voice , and his face darkened in anger before he gave a faint dismissive shrug of his broad shoulders .

Her contempt was regal .

Sir Bernard has nothing but contempt for politically embarrassing journalism .
It could be argued , in fact , that being indifferent to the consequences of one's actions indicates a high degree of contempt for ( other ) people .

She pronounced the dog 's name with special contempt .
